Name: Mrs. Henry L. Ross
Address: Kipling, Sask., R.R. 3
Birthplace: Boulder, Ont., Hamilton, Hastings County

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1912
Where did you get your homestead? Smithville, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Unknown
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, flour, tea, coffee, syrup, coal oil, oatmeal, baking powder, baking soda, green tea, castor sugar, black tea.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? First Roses and Redwood
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually two or three hundred lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 2.50
How much did you use rather flour? Not at all
Whole wheat flour? A few yrs later by the half bag
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 85¢
What other grain products did you use? Have used cracked wheat for porridge
Cornmeal? 10 lb. Bag
Whole wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By putting it through the chopper about twice for porridge about four times for graham or whole wheat flour.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Usually 50 lb. bag.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.00.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? A brand I can't remember.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 25 lb. wooden keg.

At what price? Do not remember price. But it was good.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From the cows.

Set milk pans, let cream rise overnight, skim, heat slowly.

Butter? Churned.

What was the price of butter? Twenty cents.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Dutch cheese.

What kind of cheese? Dutch cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork or beef and chicken.

How did you get fresh meat? Freeze it for winter use.

Dry salted at home.

How often did you get fresh meat? Just when you killed.

How did you preserve meat? By dry salting, smoking, with chips.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized? Towns are the closest 10 miles.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Ducks.

For how long? Just in fall, early winter.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Catch the odd fish from some of the lakes. Bought some too.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh in the beginning.

Kinds? White fish, caught from the lakes.

Usually pack fish we bought, or usually canned some.

12. WATER SUPPLY

How far was this water from your house?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1913 we had a covered in well about 4 ft from the house. This went dry. In 1915 we dug one about 4 rod from house. Drainage from a slough. This meant a lot of carrying water uphill both for the house and for the stock; and in 1946 we dug a well right by the Barn having water pumped into the Barn.
